verses.verse: And after absolutely all the large number of them got up, they led Him before Pilate.

They began to be leveling complaints against Him, saying, "We found this Person twisting the nation and hindering people to be giving protection fees to Caesar saying for He Himself to be a king, the Anointed King."
Pilate asked Him, saying, "Are You the king of the Jewish people?" When Jesus answered him, He was declaring, "You say it."
Pilate said to the head priests and the crowds, "I find no legal case in this person."
The people were getting stronger, saying, "He riles up the ethnic group teaching throughout all of Judea after beginning from Galilee to here."
When Pilate heard Galilee, he asked if the person is a Galilean.
And when he correctly understood that He is from the jurisdiction of Herod, he sent Him up to Herod, since he was also in Greater Jerusalem during these days.

When Herod saw Jesus, he was very happy. You see, he was wanting to see Him from an adequate amount of time because of the fact for him to be hearing much about Him, and he was anticipating to see some indicator happening under Him.
He was asking Him in an adequate amount of words, but He answered him nothing.
The head priests and the Old Testament transcribers had stood methodically leveling complaints against Him.
After Herod together with his armed forces treated Him as a nobody and mocked Him, after putting a dazzling outfit around Him, he sent Him up to Pilate.
They became friends (both Herod and Pilate) in the same day with each other. You see, they previously were in an enemy relationship as they were facing each other.
When Pilate called the head priests, the head people, and the group together,

he said to them, "You brought this person to me as a person who turns the ethnic group away, and look, when I investigated Him in your sight, I found no legal case in this person of the complaints that you level against Him.
But neither did Herod. You see, I sent you up to him, and look, there is nothing deserving of death that has been repeatedly done by Him.
So after I discipline Him, I will dismiss Him."
He was having an obligation to be dismissing one person to them at each festival.
But they yelled out simultaneously, saying, "Take this Person. Dismiss Barabbas to us"
(someone who, because of a certain disturbance that happened in the city and because of murder, had been thrown into jail).
So again Pilate hollered, wanting to dismiss Jesus.
But the people were hollering out, saying, "Nail Him to a cross. Nail Him to a cross."
A third time Pilate said to them, "You see, what bad thing did this Person do? I found no legal case of death in Him. So after I discipline Him, I will dismiss Him."
But the people were laying into him with loud voices asking for Him to be nailed to a cross, and the voices of them and the head priests were strong against him.
Pilate gave the sentence for their request to happen.
He dismissed to them the one who, because of disturbance and murder, had been thrown into the jail, whom they were asking for, but turned Jesus over to what they wanted.
And as they led Him away, after latching on to a certain Simon, a Cyrenian, coming out of a field, they placed the cross on him to be carrying it behind Jesus.
A very large number of the group and of women (who were also beating their chests in grief and wailing for Him) were following Him.
When Jesus turned back toward them, He said, "Daughters of Jerusalem, don't cry over Me. More importantly, cry over yourselves and over your children
because, look, days are coming in which they will state, 'The infertile women, bellies that did not give birth, and breasts that did not nurse are blessed.'
At that time, they will begin to be saying to the mountains, 'Fall on us,' and to the hills, 'Cover us up,'
because if they are doing these things in the wet wood, what will happen in the dry?"
Two different outlaws were also being led together with Him to be executed.
And when they went off onto the place, the place called Skull, there they nailed Him and the outlaws (one that was at places to the right, another that was at places to the left) to crosses.
But Jesus was saying, "Father, forgive them. You see, they don't realize what they are doing." As they thoroughly divided His clothes, they threw dice.

And the group had stood there watching. The head people were even making fun of Him out loud together with them, saying, "Others He rescued. He must rescue Himself if this is the Anointed King, the select One of God."
The soldiers also were mocking Him, coming forward, offering sour wine to Him,
and saying, "If You are the king of the Jewish people, rescue Yourself."
An inscription also had been written over Him with Greek, Latin, and Hebrew alphabetic characters, "This is the King of the Jewish people."
One of the outlaws hanging there was saying hurtful things about Him, saying, "If You are the Anointed King, rescue Yourself and us."
When the different outlaw responded, he was forbidding him, saying, "Don't you even fear God? Because you are in the same sentence,
and we, certainly rightly so. You see, we are receiving back deserving things of which we constantly did. But this person constantly did nothing out of place."
And he was saying to Jesus, "Remember me, Master, when You come in Your empire."
And Jesus said to him, "Amen, I tell you, today you will be with Me in the paradise."
It was as if it were the sixth hour (noon), and darkness happened on the whole earth until the ninth hour (3:00 p. m.).
And the sun was made dark, and the curtain of the temple was split down the middle.
And when Jesus hollered with a loud voice, He said, "Father, into Your hands will I place My spirit beside You." And when He said these things, He breathed out His last breath.
When the lieutenant saw what happened, he admitted that God is magnificent, saying, "This person was really right."
And all the crowds that came out together on this spectator event, after watching what happened, were returning hitting their own chests.
All the people known of Him and the women who followed along with Him out of Galilee had stood at a distance looking at these things.
And look, a man with the name Joseph, an advisor, who was a good man and did what is right.
This man, who had not voted for their intention and what they repeatedly did, was from Arimathaea, a city of the Jewish people, who also even himself was awaiting the empire of God.
This man, after going forward to Pilate, asked for the body of Jesus.
And when he took it down, he wound a linen cloth around it and placed Him in a grave cut out of rock that no one was lying in yet.
And the day was a preparation day, and a Sabbath was emerging.
After women also (some who had come together from Galilee) followed behind him, they viewed the burial vault and how His body was placed.
When they returned, they got fragrant spices and perfumes ready. And they certainly calmed down on the Sabbath according to the demand.
